---

**üìò Conditional Access - Summaries, Insights, Security & Monitoring (CA-SISM)** serves as a robust tool for administrators looking to gain deep insights into their organization‚Äôs Conditional Access (CA) policies. Here's a breakdown of the key features:

---

## üìå Key Features:

| Feature | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| üéØ **Dynamic Reporting** | Real-time insights into tenant-defined Conditional Access policies using `AuditLogs` & `SigninLogs`. [Visualization requirements](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/monitoring-health/workbook-mfa-gaps). |
| üß† **Insights & Summaries** | Analyze sign-in activities, assess policy effectiveness, and uncover coverage gaps. |
| üìã **Report-Only Policy Data** | Evaluate policies in report-only mode to measure potential impact without enforcement. |
| üîç **In-Depth Insights** | View trends on device platforms, states, sign-in risk, and client app usage. |
| üîÑ **What If Analysis** | Run simulated outcomes using data from the workbook and Microsoft‚Äôs What If tool. |
| üÜò **Emergency Account Monitoring** | Track emergency accounts to ensure they're not blocked by CA policies. |

---

In essence, the **Conditional Access ‚Äì Summaries, Insight, Security & Monitoring (CA-SISM) Workbook** simplifies policy validation, enhances security measures, and safeguards emergency accounts. It's a vital resource for managing effective conditional access configurations.

---

## üß≠ Further Guidance ‚Äì Baseline Conditional Access Deployment Templates

To adhere to a Zero Trust framework, **conditional access templates** provide a streamlined approach for implementing new policies based on Microsoft's best practices. Tailored for robust protection, these templates follow widely adopted practices across various customer types and regions.  
For more information on template categories, please review [**Tailored Templates**](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-policy-common?tabs=secure-foundation#template-categories).

---

## üõ°Ô∏è Additional Tools to Advance Zero Trust Initiatives

| Tool | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **ü§ø [CISA SCUBA](https://github.com/cisagov/ScubaGear)** | The Secure Cloud Business Applications (SCuBA) project provides guidance to secure cloud environments and protect federal information. |
| **‚öôÔ∏è [Maester](https://maester.dev/docs/intro)** | A PowerShell-based test automation framework to help manage your Microsoft security configurations. |
| **üì• [Entra ID Security Config Analyzer (EIDSCA)](https://github.com/Cloud-Architekt/AzureAD-Attack-Defense/blob/main/AADSecurityConfigAnalyzer.md)** | Provides a solution for pulling Entra ID security configurations from Microsoft Graph API endpoints into Log Analytics, with support for Sentinel alerts on critical configuration changes. |
| **üõ°Ô∏è [Microsoft DoD Zero Trust Strategy](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2024/04/16/new-microsoft-guidance-for-the-dod-zero-trust-strategy/)** | A roadmap for achieving enterprise-wide Zero Trust by 2027, detailing activities for DoD and Defense Industrial Base partners. |
| **üìò [Microsoft CISA Zero Trust Strategy](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2024/12/19/new-microsoft-guidance-for-the-cisa-zero-trust-maturity-model/)** | Helps agencies develop and mature their Zero Trust strategies using the CISA Zero Trust Maturity Model (ZTMM). |

---

## üîÑ Quick Start Guide to CA-SISM

> üí° **Want to unlock full visibility into your Conditional Access policies? Start here:**
> 
> - ‚úÖ Ingest `AuditLogs` and `SigninLogs` into your Log Analytics workspace  
> - üìã Explore and apply [**Microsoft‚Äôs tailored Conditional Access templates**](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-policy-common?tabs=secure-foundation#template-categories)  
> 
> üß≠ These steps streamline configuration, power your dashboards, and turn raw log data into actionable insights.

### üë§ Conditional Access for Users  

Conditional Access is the **Zero Trust policy engine** at the heart of Microsoft Entra ID üîë. It evaluates real-time signals like **user identity üë§**, **device compliance üíª**, **location üåç**, and **sign-in risk üîé** to enforce adaptive access decisions. Instead of a single static gate, it applies **if‚Äìthen logic** (e.g., *if a user is signing in from an unmanaged device, then require MFA or block access*). This ensures the right balance of **security üõ°Ô∏è** and **productivity üöÄ** ‚Äî granting users access when safe, and challenging or blocking when risk is detected.  

üëâ Learn more: [Conditional Access overview](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/overview)  

---

‚ö†Ô∏è **Disclaimer**  
This workbook is intended as an **insight and troubleshooting aid** for Conditional Access authentication flows. Use the available parameters (**UserPrincipalName, Application, Policy, Report, Region, Location, SignInRisk, UserRisk**) as **filters** to narrow results to your area of focus. Without filtering, the output may be too broad to interpret effectively within a single workbook view.

// Objective: Summarize Conditional Access sign-in results by policy, app, location, user risk, and sign-in risk
SigninLogs
| mv-expand ConditionalAccessPolicies
| evaluate bag_unpack(LocationDetails)
| extend 
    Result             = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.result),
    ['PolicyName']     = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.displayName),
    UserRisk           = tostring(RiskLevelDuringSignIn),
    SigninRisk         = tostring(RiskDetail),
    AzureADApplication = tostring(AppDisplayName),
    Region             = Location
| where ['PolicyName']       in~ ({Policy})
  and AzureADApplication     in~ ({Application})
  and state                  in~ ({Location})
  and Region                 in~ ({Region})
  and Result                 in~ ({Report})
  and UserRisk               in~ ({UserRisk})
  and SigninRisk             in~ ({SignInRisk})
  and UserPrincipalName contains ('{UserPrincipalName}')
| summarize Count = count() by Result
| order by Count desc

content.json:
## üìä **Conditional Access Insights & Reporting**

#### The following are the types of reports available for Conditional Access. Use them with the [What If tool](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/what-if-tool) in [Commercial](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_ConditionalAccess/WhatIfBlade) or [Government](https://entra.microsoft.us/#view/Microsoft_AAD_ConditionalAccess/WhatIfBlade) environments. Select any item below to view more detailed output.

| **Status** | **Description** |
|------------|-----------------|
| ‚úÖ **Success** | Policy successfully granted access. User met all required conditions (device, location, security settings). |
| ‚ùå **Failure** | Policy blocked access. Resource did not meet policy conditions. |
| üö´ **Not Enabled** | Policy and conditions are disabled. |
| ‚è≥ **Not Applied** | Policy not enforced for any user or group. |
| üìã **Report-only: Success** | Conditions and required controls satisfied. For example, MFA claim or compliant device check. |
| ‚ö†Ô∏è **Report-only: Failure** | Conditions satisfied, but not all controls met. E.g., block control applied or non-compliant device. |
| üõë **Report-only: User Action Required** | Conditions satisfied, but user action needed for controls. E.g., MFA prompt not shown. |
| üö∑ **Report-only: Not Applied** | Not all conditions met (e.g., user excluded or limited to specific trusted locations). |

### üí° **Key Takeaways:**
Use these summaries with the **What If** tool to track policy effectiveness and fine-tune Conditional Access configurations.

## üîç **Analyzing Conditional Access Results**

The results below provide a **policy outcome view** with details such as grant controls, risk levels, and authentication context.

### ‚ú® **How to Read the Results**
- üîÑ **Excluding Previously Satisfied**  
  The lower grid automatically filters out *previously satisfied* conditions. This ensures the view highlights the **actual authentication method** enforced during the session.  

- üß© **Click the CorrelationId**  
  Each user sign-in event has a **CorrelationId**. Click it to open a **detailed pane** that shows the *success or failure path*, including where policies were **previously satisfied**.  

- üéØ **Policy Effectiveness**  
  Drill-downs help confirm whether access was ‚úÖ granted, ‚ùå blocked, or ‚è≥ skipped based on the specific Conditional Access rule in play.  

- üîë **Authentication Method Check**  
  Use this section to verify whether controls like **MFA**, **compliant device**, or **trusted location** were the ones truly enforced at runtime.

content.query:
// Objective: Summarize Conditional Access sign-in details with authentication methods and named locations
SigninLogs
// --- Expand arrays first ---
| mv-expand AuthenticationDetail = todynamic(AuthenticationDetails)
| mv-expand ConditionalAccessPolicies
| evaluate bag_unpack(LocationDetails)
| extend LocationDetails = iff(array_length(parse_json(NetworkLocationDetails)) == 0, dynamic([{}]), parse_json(NetworkLocationDetails))
| mv-expand LocationDetails
| mv-expand networkName = LocationDetails.networkNames
// --- Extend fields together ---
| extend 
    AuthMethod       = tostring(AuthenticationDetail.authenticationMethod),
    AuthRequirement  = tostring(AuthenticationDetail.authenticationRequirement),
    AuthResult       = tostring(AuthenticationDetail.resultDetail),
    Result           = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.result),
    ['PolicyName']   = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.displayName),
    ['Grant Control']= tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.enforcedGrantControls),
    Application      = tostring(AppDisplayName),
    Locale           = state,
    Region           = Location,
    LocationName     = tostring(parse_json(tostring(parse_json(NetworkLocationDetails)[0].networkNames))[0]),
    SignInRisk       = tostring(RiskDetail),
    UserRisk         = tostring(RiskLevelDuringSignIn),
    DeviceDetails    = tolower(DeviceDetail)
// --- Where filters grouped together ---
| where AuthMethod <> "Previously satisfied"
  and ['PolicyName']       in~ ({Policy})
  and Application          in~ ({Application})
  and Result               in~ ({Report})
  and UserPrincipalName contains ('{UserPrincipalName}')
  and UserRisk             in~ ({UserRisk})
  and SignInRisk           in~ ({SignInRisk})
  and Locale               in~ ({Location})
  and Region               in~ ({Region})
// --- Final summarize ---
| summarize ['Named Locations'] = make_set(tostring(networkName))
    by TimeGenerated, CorrelationId, UserPrincipalName, Application, AuthMethod, 
       IP = IPAddress, Region, Locale, ['PolicyName'], ClientAppUsed, 
       SignInRisk, UserRisk, Result, ['Grant Control'], DeviceDetails
| order by TimeGenerated desc
content.title: Analyzing Conditional Access Results for What-If Tool. Select a 'TimeGenerated' For Further Details. Search to filter further.

items.name: Analyzing Conditional Access Results for What-If Tool. Select a 'TimeGenerated' For Further Details

content.query:
// Objective: Show authentication step details for a specific Conditional Access policy, result, and timestamp
SigninLogs
// --- Expand arrays first ---
| mv-expand ConditionalAccessPolicies
| mv-expand AuthDetails = todynamic(AuthenticationDetails)
// --- Extend fields together ---
| extend 
    ['PolicyName']           = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.displayName),
    Result                   = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.result),
    AuthNMethod              = tostring(AuthDetails.authenticationMethod),
    AuthNStepReq             = tostring(AuthDetails.authenticationStepRequirement),
    AuthNStepResultDetails   = tostring(AuthDetails.authenticationStepResultDetail),
    Succession               = tostring(AuthDetails.succeeded)
// --- Where filters grouped together ---
| where ['PolicyName'] == "{pol2}"
  and Result == "{result2}"
  and TimeGenerated == "{Time2}"
// --- Final projection and sort ---
| project TimeGenerated, CorrelationId, ['PolicyName'], UserPrincipalName, 
          AuthNMethod, AuthNStepReq, AuthNStepResultDetails, Succession, 
          Result, ResultType, ResultDescription
| sort by TimeGenerated desc

content.json:
### üîê Conditional Access for Workload Identities  

Workload identities (like service principals and app registrations) power automation and apps, but they **can‚Äôt use MFA** and often rely on secrets or certificates üóùÔ∏è. That makes them a **prime attack target üéØ**. With Conditional Access for workload identities, you can enforce **location üåç**, **risk-based üîé**, and **app-specific üì¶** policies ‚Äî bringing Zero Trust protections to non-human accounts ü§ñ.  

üëâ Learn more: [Conditional Access for workload identities](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/workload-identity)  

---

‚ö†Ô∏è **Disclaimer**  
This workbook is designed to provide **insight into Conditional Access for workload identities** and to help troubleshoot authentication flows. Use the parameters (**Workload Identity, Resource, Policy, Report, Region, RiskLevel**) as **filters** to focus on specific scenarios. Without filtering, the dataset may be too large, making it harder to isolate meaningful insights within a single workbook view.

content.query:
// Objective: Summarize Service Principal sign-in results by result type and SP name
AADServicePrincipalSignInLogs
// --- Expand arrays first ---
| mv-expand ConditionalAccessPolicies = todynamic(ConditionalAccessPolicies)
// --- Extend fields together ---
| extend 
    Result         = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.result),
    ['PolicyName'] = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.displayName),
    Locale         = iff(isempty(Location), "NoLocale", tostring(parse_json(LocationDetails).state)),
    Region         = iff(isempty(Location), "NoRegion", Location),
    City           = iff(isempty(Location), "NoCity", tostring(parse_json(LocationDetails).city))
// --- Where filters grouped together ---
| where ['PolicyName']       in~ ({PolicyWI})
  and ResourceDisplayName    in~ ({ResourceWI})
  and Result                 in~ ({ReportWI})
  and ServicePrincipalName   in~ ({WI})
  and Region                 in~ ({RegionWI})
  and Locale                 in~ ({LocationWI})         
| join kind=leftouter AADRiskyServicePrincipals on $left.AppId == $right.AppId //AADServicePrincipalRiskEvents ‚Äì this is the data that you would see in Azure AD Identity Protection if you went and viewed the risk detections, or risky sign-in reports
| extend RiskLevel = iff(isempty(RiskLevel), "NoRisk", RiskLevel)
| where RiskLevel in~ ({RiskLevelWI})
// --- Summarize ---
| summarize Count = count() by Result, ServicePrincipalName
| order by Count desc

## üìä **Conditional Access Insights & Reporting**

#### The following are the types of reports available for Conditional Access. Use them with the [What If tool](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/what-if-tool) in [Commercial](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_ConditionalAccess/WhatIfBlade) or [Government](https://entra.microsoft.us/#view/Microsoft_AAD_ConditionalAccess/WhatIfBlade) environments. Select any item below to view more detailed output.

| **Status** | **Description** |
|------------|-----------------|
| ‚úÖ **Success** | Policy successfully granted access. User met all required conditions (device, location, security settings). |
| ‚ùå **Failure** | Policy blocked access. Resource did not meet policy conditions. |
| üö´ **Not Enabled** | Policy and conditions are disabled. |
| ‚è≥ **Not Applied** | Policy not enforced for any user or group. |
| üìã **Report-only: Success** | Conditions and required controls satisfied. For example, MFA claim or compliant device check. |
| ‚ö†Ô∏è **Report-only: Failure** | Conditions satisfied, but not all controls met. E.g., block control applied or non-compliant device. |
| üõë **Report-only: User Action Required** | Conditions satisfied, but user action needed for controls. E.g., MFA prompt not shown. |
| üö∑ **Report-only: Not Applied** | Not all conditions met (e.g., user excluded or limited to specific trusted locations). |

### üí° **Key Takeaways:**
Use these summaries with the **What If** tool to track policy effectiveness and fine-tune Conditional Access configurations.

// Objective: Summarize Service Principal sign-ins with Conditional Access and Risk info

    Result          = tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.result),

    ['Grant Control']= tostring(ConditionalAccessPolicies.enforcedGrantControls),
    IPAddress       = tostring(coalesce(column_ifexists("IPAddress",""), "")),
    Region          = iff(isempty(Location), "NoRegion", Location),
    Locale          = iff(isempty(Location), "NoLocale", tostring(parse_json(LocationDetails).state)),
    City            = iff(isempty(Location), "NoCity", tostring(parse_json(LocationDetails).city)),
    Status          = ResultSignature,
    ['Status Error']= ResultType
// --- Join risky SPs ---
| join kind=leftouter AADRiskyServicePrincipals on $left.AppId == $right.AppId
// --- Extend risk fields ---
| extend RiskLevel = iff(isempty(RiskLevel), "NoRisk", RiskLevel)
// --- Where filters grouped together ---
| where (ServicePrincipalName in~ ({WI}) or DisplayName in~ ({WI}))
  and ResourceDisplayName    in~ ({ResourceWI})
  and ['PolicyName']         in~ ({PolicyWI})
  and Result                 in~ ({ReportWI})
  and Region                 in~ ({RegionWI})
  and RiskLevel              in~ ({RiskLevelWI})
  and Locale                 in~ ({LocationWI})

// --- Final projection ---
| distinct TimeGenerated = todatetime(TimeGenerated),
           CorrelationId, ServicePrincipalName, ResourceDisplayName,
           IPAddress, Region, City, Locale, ['PolicyName'],
           ['Grant Control'], RiskLevel, Result, Status, ['Status Error']

content.json:
## üö® Conditional Access Emergency Account ‚Äì Creation

Emergency accounts ‚Äî also known as **"Break Glass" accounts** ‚Äî are essential safeguards for maintaining control over your Microsoft Entra environment during critical scenarios.

üîç **What is an Emergency Account?**  
Emergency access accounts are **highly privileged** accounts not assigned to specific individuals. These accounts are strictly for use during emergency or lockout scenarios, where standard admin accounts are unavailable.

üîó [**Review Microsoft‚Äôs guidance on managing emergency access**](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/security-emergency-access?WT.mc_id=Portal-fx)

> üí° *Why it matters:*  
> Avoid getting locked out of your Microsoft Entra organization. Emergency accounts help mitigate risks by ensuring you can regain access even if normal admin credentials fail.

### üõ°Ô∏è Best Practices
- Create **at least two** emergency accounts.
- Limit their use to **genuine emergencies** only.
- Regularly monitor, document, and audit their usage.

---

### üß± **Step 1: Create Emergency Access Accounts**  
Follow Microsoft's official guide for proper setup:  
üìò [How to create an emergency access account](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/security-emergency-access?WT.mc_id=Portal-fx#how-to-create-an-emergency-access-account)

## üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Conditional Access Emergency Account ‚Äì Monitor Sign-In

### üß≠ Step 2 ‚Äì Monitor Sign-In Events & Create Alert Rules

Keeping emergency accounts secure requires **proactive monitoring**. Configure alert rules to detect unexpected or unauthorized sign-ins from these accounts.

üîî **Set up Alert Rules with Azure Monitor**  
Use [Azure Monitor](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/security-emergency-access?WT.mc_id=Portal-fx#create-an-alert-rule) to track emergency sign-ins and receive real-time alerts for unusual activity.

üõ°Ô∏è **Enhanced Detection with Microsoft Sentinel**  
Microsoft Sentinel includes built-in Conditional Access analytics as part of the Entra content. These rules provide real-time detection for CA policy changes, risky bypasses, and activity involving break-glass accounts ‚Äî all without custom KQL.
Enable these rules under Sentinel ‚Üí Analytics ‚Üí Microsoft Entra ID to strengthen your monitoring after installing via Sentinel Content Hub.

### üßæ Key Configuration Notes:
- Use the full `UserPrincipalName` or `UserId` of each emergency account.
- Limit your scope to **two accounts maximum**, reflecting best practices for emergency access.
- Regularly review and update alert conditions to match your organizational risk profile.

> üö® *Monitoring these accounts is not optional‚Äîit‚Äôs critical for identifying unauthorized use and ensuring compliance with least-privilege principles.*

---

> ‚úèÔ∏è **Action Required:**  
> To ensure accurate monitoring, be sure to enter the **full User Principal Name (UPN)** or **User ID (Object ID)** of each emergency account when configuring alert rules or analytics queries.
> This ensures the system can precisely identify and track the correct accounts ‚Äî especially in environments with similarly named users or service principals.
> Where applicable, you can also filter by **Authentication Method** to capture details on how these accounts authenticated (e.g., password only, FIDO2, certificate, etc.).

| where UserPrincipalName == '{UPN1}' or UserPrincipalName == '{UPN2}' or UserId == '{UserID1}' or UserId == '{UserID2}' 
| extend AuthDetails = todynamic(AuthenticationDetails)
| extend ['FA-AuthMethod'] = tostring(AuthDetails[0].authenticationMethod)
| project ['FA-AuthMethod'];
union 
(
    SignInData
),
(
    // Only include fallback if no rows in SignInData
    print ['FA-AuthMethod'] = "NoAuthMethod"
    | where (toscalar(SignInData | count) == 0)
)
| distinct ['FA-AuthMethod']

| extend 
    ['FA-RequestSequence']    = tostring(parse_json(AuthenticationDetails)[0].RequestSequence),

## üõ°Ô∏è Designing Emergency Access Groups for Scoped Conditional Access Exceptions

### üß≠ Strategic Grouping for Break-Glass Account Management

For organizations that leverage **group nesting** and, where applicable, **Restricted Administrative Units (RAUs)** to strengthen Conditional Access (CA) controls, it‚Äôs recommended to create two dedicated Entra security groups:

- **EmergencyAccess01**  
- **EmergencyAccess02**  

‚ö†Ô∏è Some organizations choose to veer away from this approach and instead manage their **emergency accounts individually through dedicated CA policies**. While this method can provide direct policy visibility per account, it often introduces additional administrative overhead and greater risk of policy drift.  

By establishing either the **group-based model** or carefully maintaining **per-account policies**, organizations can ensure that emergency access remains both resilient and tightly governed in alignment with Zero Trust principles.

These groups act as **centralized and auditable anchors** for CA exclusions‚Äîenabling robust policy enforcement without broad overreach.

---

### üîê Why This Structure Matters:

- Enforces **distinct authentication and authorization** boundaries  
- Provides **auditable separation** of emergency access logic  
- Supports **RAU-based role scoping** to reduce blast radius (when RAUs are used)  
- Enables **focused CA exclusions via the group**, not the RAU

> ‚ö†Ô∏è *Important*: Conditional Access policies cannot be scoped directly to RAUs. Instead, scope policies to the **emergency access groups**, which may themselves be protected via RAUs.

---

### üßæ Configuration Best Practices:

- Use exactly **two emergency accounts**, each in its own group  
- Group names must **match automation variables and scripts** exactly  
- Additional accounts should be treated as **temporary exceptions** and regularly reviewed

> üö® **Prevent privilege sprawl**: Any unjustified break-glass accounts must be removed immediately.

---

### ‚úèÔ∏è Action Required:

‚úÖ Regardless of the naming convention, ensure these groups (or equivalent emergency access accounts) are **actively registered in automation tooling and surfaced in monitoring dashboards**. This is critical to maintain visibility, validate usage, and preserve policy integrity.

content.query:
AuditLogs
| where OperationName in (
    "Add member to group", 
    "Remove member from group", 
    "Add member to restricted management administrative unit", 
    "Remove member from restricted management administrative unit"
)
| where (strlen('{EG01}') > 0 and TargetResources contains '{EG01}')
    or (strlen('{EG02}') > 0 and TargetResources contains '{EG02}')
    or (strlen('{RAU01}') > 0 and TargetResources contains '{RAU01}')
    or (strlen('{RAU02}') > 0 and TargetResources contains '{RAU02}')
| extend Actor = tostring(parse_json(tostring(InitiatedBy.user)).userPrincipalName)
| extend OldValue = tostring(parse_json(tostring(parse_json(tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties))[1].oldValue)))
| extend NewValue = tostring(parse_json(tostring(parse_json(tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties))[1].newValue)))
| extend AuditedGroupOrRAU = coalesce(OldValue, NewValue)
// Unified handling for member changes
| extend PrincipalAddedOrRemoved = case(
        OperationName in ("Add member to group", "Remove member from group"),
            coalesce(
                tostring(TargetResources[0].userPrincipalName),
                tostring(TargetResources[0].servicePrincipalName),
                tostring(TargetResources[0].displayName),
                tostring(TargetResources[0].id)
            ),
        OperationName in ("Add member to restricted management administrative unit", "Remove member from restricted management administrative unit"),
            coalesce(
                tostring(TargetResources[0].userPrincipalName),
                tostring(TargetResources[0].servicePrincipalName),
                tostring(TargetResources[0].displayName),
                tostring(TargetResources[0].id)
            ),
        ""
    )
| extend GroupAddedToRAU = iif(OperationName == "Add member to restricted management administrative unit", tostring(TargetResources[0].displayName), "")
| extend GroupRemovedFromRAU = iif(OperationName == "Remove member from restricted management administrative unit", tostring(TargetResources[0].displayName), "")
| project TimeGenerated, OperationName, Actor, AuditedGroupOrRAU, PrincipalAddedOrRemoved, GroupAddedToRAU, GroupRemovedFromRAU
| order by TimeGenerated desc

## üîç Monitoring Conditional Access Exclusion Group Changes

Track changes to the **users or groups** that are **added or removed** from Conditional Access policy exclusions. This audit view specifically monitors updates by **Object ID only**, providing visibility into who has been granted or revoked exclusion from CA enforcement.

> üìå **Note**: This report captures the **Object ID**, not the resolved display name or UPN. To enhance the results, you may use correlation queries or Entra ID lookups.

In audit logs, any automated service or process making Conditional Access changes‚Äîsuch as Microsoft‚Äôs **Managed Policy Manager**‚Äîwill now appear under the `APP` field in KQL queries. The `APP` field identifies application-based actions, whether initiated by internal automation tools or by Microsoft.

This setup helps identify and track who is making changes to your exclusion groups, whether it's a user performing the update manually or an automated process.

content.json:
## üîç Monitoring Dynamic Group Rule Changes for Conditional Access Exclusions

Track changes to **Dynamic Membership Rules** for specific Entra ID groups, particularly those used in **Conditional Access (CA) policy exclusions**. This workbook view helps detect when a dynamic rule is altered‚Äîwhether by an admin or an automated process‚Äîpotentially impacting the scope of a CA policy.

üõ†Ô∏è **How it works:**  
This query monitors `AuditLogs` for `Update group` operations where the group's membership is defined by a dynamic rule (`DynamicMembership`). It filters to groups of interest based on user-defined parameters.

üìå **Parameters:**
- `{dynamic1}` ‚Äî The name (or partial name) of the first group you want to monitor.  
- `{dynamic2}` ‚Äî The name (or partial name) of the second group you want to monitor (optional).

üîê **Use Case:**  
Dynamic groups often drive conditional access exclusions for device trust, compliance, or other identity-based signals. Monitoring for changes to these group rules is essential for preventing misconfigurations or unauthorized privilege expansion.

‚ö†Ô∏è **Why it matters:**  
Changes to dynamic membership rules can silently broaden or narrow access for devices and users. Since CA policies can depend on these groups for enforcement exclusions, an unnoticed rule update can undermine your Zero Trust strategy.

üß† **Pro Tip:**  
Use this in combination with Conditional Access policy change tracking to correlate group rule edits with Conditional Access behavior shifts.

content.query:
AuditLogs
| where OperationName == "Update group"
| mv-expand detail = AdditionalDetails
| where detail.value == "DynamicMembership"
| extend DynamicGroupName = tostring(TargetResources[0].displayName)
//| where DynamicGroupName contains '{dynamic1}' or DynamicGroupName contains '{dynamic2}'  // Directly using the params here
| where (strlen('{dynamic1}') > 0 and DynamicGroupName contains '{dynamic1}')
    or (strlen('{dynamic2}') > 0 and DynamicGroupName contains '{dynamic2}')
| extend modifiedBy = tostring(InitiatedBy.user.userPrincipalName)
| extend accountName = tostring(split(modifiedBy, "@")[0])
| extend upnSuffix = tostring(split(modifiedBy, "@")[1])
| extend oldRule = tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties[0].oldValue)
| extend newRule = tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties[0].newValue)
| where oldRule != newRule
| project
    TimeGenerated,
    OperationName,
    DynamicGroupName,
    modifiedBy,
    accountName,
    upnSuffix,
    result = Result,
    oldRule,
    newRule
| order by TimeGenerated desc

## üìä Conditional Access ‚Äì Monitoring

### üìù Change History & Audit Context

Below are visuals highlighting the **change history**, **top policy editors**, and **correlation data** for Conditional Access activity.

In audit logs, any automated service or process making Conditional Access changes‚Äîsuch as Microsoft‚Äôs **Managed Policy Manager**‚Äîwill now appear under the `APP` field in KQL queries. The `APP` field identifies application-based actions, whether initiated by internal automation tools or by Microsoft.

If your organization utilizes any application to interact with Conditional Access policies, or if Microsoft pushes changes, you‚Äôll see those events attributed to the relevant application name in the `APP` column.

---

### üîê Microsoft Sentinel Integration

For **Microsoft Sentinel** customers, it‚Äôs recommended to create custom **Analytics Rules** using KQL to monitor `Create`, `Update`, and `Delete` operations on Conditional Access policies.

To streamline deployment, refer to this solution:  
[Conditional Access with Microsoft Sentinel](https://jeffreyappel.nl/monitor-azure-ad-break-glass-accounts-with-azure-sentinel/)

This approach will enhance visibility and auditing for both **manual** and **automated** policy changes.

content.query:
let OldPolicy = AuditLogs
| where CorrelationId == "{SelectedCorrelationId}"
| where OperationName in ("Add conditional access policy", "Update conditional access policy", "Delete conditional access policy")
| mv-expand InitiatedBy
| extend User = tostring(parse_json(tostring(InitiatedBy.user)).userPrincipalName)
| extend APP = tostring(parse_json(tostring(InitiatedBy.app)).displayName)
| extend User = iff(isempty(User), "NA", User)
| extend APP = iff(isempty(APP), "NA", APP)
| extend Policy = todynamic(tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties[0].oldValue))
| project Policy, User, APP
| extend version = "OldVersion";
let NewPolicy = AuditLogs
| where CorrelationId == "{SelectedCorrelationId}"
| where OperationName in ("Add conditional access policy", "Update conditional access policy", "Delete conditional access policy")
| mv-expand InitiatedBy
| extend User = tostring(parse_json(tostring(InitiatedBy.user)).userPrincipalName)
| extend APP = tostring(parse_json(tostring(InitiatedBy.app)).displayName)
| extend User = iff(isempty(User), "NA", User)
| extend APP = iff(isempty(APP), "NA", APP)
| extend Policy = todynamic(tostring(TargetResources[0].modifiedProperties[0].newValue))
| project Policy, User, APP
| extend version = "NewVersion";
union OldPolicy, NewPolicy
| order by version asc
| extend grantControls = todynamic("")
| extend sessionControls = todynamic("")
| evaluate bag_unpack(Policy, columnsConflict = 'replace_source')
| evaluate bag_unpack(conditions, columnsConflict = 'replace_source')
| evaluate bag_unpack(grantControls, columnsConflict = 'replace_source')
| evaluate bag_unpack(sessionControls, columnsConflict = 'replace_source')
